definition: seriously ill and about to die
full/to fill/completely/more
brimming or overflowing
old variant of 留[liu2]
to leave (a message etc)/to retain/to stay/to remain/to keep/to preserve
old variant of 留[liu2]
on one's deathbed/at the point of death

sentences.english: The wise old Mother Superior was dying.
sentences.chinese: 睿智的老女修道院长处在了弥留之际。

sentences.english: Near death, the farmer called his clever son to his side.
sentences.chinese: 弥留之际，农夫叫聪明的老大到他的身边。

sentences.english: The mercury sank in the mouth of the dying day.
sentences.chinese: 水银柱沉入了弥留之日的口中。

sentences.english: However plum one day a thin continue, and finally to happen.
sentences.chinese: 但是梅子一天天瘦了下去，终于到了弥留之际。

sentences.english: So, painstakingly, he combed the thatch of the past.
sentences.chinese: 在弥留之际，他艰难地梳理密密麻麻的往事。

sentences.english: In his last time Hassan let Nassau lead the whole caravan.
sentences.chinese: 弥留之际，老人把整个商队的命运和未来交给了儿子。

sentences.english: In the moribund patient deepening coma are the usual preludes to death.
sentences.chinese: 病人弥留之际，加深的昏睡通常是死的前兆。

sentences.english: Live as you will have wished to have lived when you are dying.
sentences.chinese: 要过上你弥留之际所希望的生活。

sentences.english: Blade holding point of wheat, loudly interrogation xishi eventually is who.
sentences.chinese: 刀锋抱着弥留的麦子，大声讯问西施终究是谁。

definition: on one's deathbed/at the point of death
approaching one's end/with one foot in the grave
dying
final radiance of setting sun/fig. dying flash (of lucidity or activity, prior to demise)
to bid farewell/to part (usually with little hope of meeting again)
suddenly
to elapse/to pass away/to die/demise
to checkmate (in chess)/to be about to die
eternal rest (i.e. death)
one's late days/to have one foot in the grave
sickbed
to approach one's coffin (idiom); with one foot in the grave
to die/to leave this world
lit. to fly on a crane to the Western Paradise/fig. to pass away (idiom)
the world/this world/the world of the living
to come to/to awaken/to regain consciousness
